data.title: Naming Convention Identifier
data.solution:
# snake_case, SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE, camelCase, PascalCase, flatcase, UPPERFLATCASE, kebab-case, SCREAMING-KEBAB-CASE
n = gets.to_i
n.times do
  variable = gets.chomp
  has_upper = variable.match?(/[A-Z]/)
  has_lower = variable.match?(/[a-z]/)
  starts_upper = variable.match?(/^[A-Z]/)
  has_hyphen = variable.include?("-")
  has_underscore = variable.include?("_")
  if has_hyphen
    puts has_upper ? "SCREAMING-KEBAB-CASE" : "kebab-case"
  elsif has_underscore
    puts has_upper ? "SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE" : "snake_case"
  else
    if starts_upper
      puts has_lower ? "PascalCase" : "UPPERFLATCASE"
    else
      puts has_upper ? "camelCase" : "flatcase"
    end
  end
end
data.statement:
There are lots of naming conventions used in programming. Given [[n]] [[variables]], print their naming conventions.

<<The possible conventions are:>>

{{flatcase}} (only lowercase letters)

{{UPPERFLATCASE}} (only uppercase letters)

{{camelCase}} (upper and lowercase letters, starting with a lowercase)

{{PascalCase}} (upper and lowercase letters, starting with an uppercase)

{{snake_case}} (only lowercase letters and underscores)

{{SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE}} (only uppercase letters and underscores)

{{kebab-case}} (only lowercase letters and hyphens)

{{SCREAMING-KEBAB-CASE}} (only uppercase letters and hyphens)

<<Note:>> In this clash, any [[variable]] fitting a convention other than {{flatcase}} or {{UPPERFLATCASE}} will always include at least two words, meaning it can be identified by a mix of letter cases, hyphens and/or underscores.

SCREAMING-KEBAB-CASE

camelCase

data.constraints:
1 ≤ [[n]] ≤ 10
To simplify things, there will be no digits in any [[variable]] names: only letters, underscores and hyphens.
All tests will contain valid cases (no mixtures of incompatible conventions).

snake_case, SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE, camelCase, PascalCase, flatcase, UPPERFLATCASE, kebab-case, SCREAMING-KEBAB-CASE

<<Line 1 :>> [[n]], the number of [[variables]] to categorise by naming convention

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

There are lots of naming conventions used in programming. Given n variables, print their naming conventions.

The possible conventions are:

flatcase (only lowercase letters)

UPPERFLATCASE (only uppercase letters)

camelCase (upper and lowercase letters, starting with a lowercase)

PascalCase (upper and lowercase letters, starting with an uppercase)

snake_case (only lowercase letters and underscores)

SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE (only uppercase letters and underscores)

kebab-case (only lowercase letters and hyphens)

SCREAMING-KEBAB-CASE (only uppercase letters and hyphens)

Note: In this clash, any variable fitting a convention other than flatcase or UPPERFLATCASE will always include at least two words, meaning it can be identified by a mix of letter cases, hyphens and/or underscores.
Input
Line 1 : n, the number of variables to categorise by naming convention
Next n lines : a variable in one of the formats listed, to be categorised
Output
n lines : the naming convention that each variable fits
Constraints
1 ≤ n ≤ 10
To simplify things, there will be no digits in any variable names: only letters, underscores and hyphens.
All tests will contain valid cases (no mixtures of incompatible conventions).
Example
Input
2
variableOne
VARIABLETWO
Output
camelCase
UPPERFLATCASE
